none: Performance at Soldier Field and Strike up the Band
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music (Contributor)
From 00:09:07-00:46:44, image is frozen and audio of Strike Up the Band and from the November 16, 1991 Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Iowa Hawkeyes is heard. (General Note)
Strike Up the Band is shown a total of 3 times on this VHS tape. (General Note)
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music
Willson, Meredith, 1902-1984. Music man. Seventy-six trombones
Gershwin, George, 1898-1937. Strike up the band
Rodgers, Richard, 1902-1979. Sound of music. Do-re-mi

On November 3, 1991 the Northwestern University Marching Band performs the halftime show at a Chicago Bears' game at Soldier Field in Chicago, Illinois. The performance includes "Ya Gotta Try," La Suerte de los Tontos," "Alexander's Ragtime Band," and "Go U Northwestern." Following the performance at Soldier Field is Strike Up the Band. A behind-the-scenes look at preparations for the 1960 Northwestern University Marching Band season. Footage includes conductor John P. Paynter discussing fundamentals with band members, practice drills, and Paynter planning some of the Northwestern University Marching Band's most popular formations. Former conductor Glenn Cliffe Bainum wishes the band luck before their first performance. Highlights from that first performance include "Strike Up the Band," "Seventy-Six Trombones," a polka, "Relax," and "Do-Re-Mi." The performances also feature sibling twirlers Roger and Barbara Kurucz. Strike Up the Band is shown two additional times.

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
